title: Mocking nested smart components with mocha
body:
Hi,

I'm trying to test a "smart" connected component that has another connect'ed child inside.
Preparing a store for the test and providing it directly

``` js
TestUtils.renderIntoDocument(
    <SmartParent store={store} />
);
```

and SmartParent has `<SmartChild />` in it that throws an exception like `Either wrap the root component in a <Provider>, or explicitly pass "store"...`

I know there's `rewire`, but I couldn't manage babel\webpack\karma\rewire setup easily, so I went with making the `SmartChild` dumb for now. But I really would like to figure testing thing out.
Any hints on this? Maybe some working examples?

Thanks!
author: gothy

comments.body:
``` js
TestUtils.renderIntoDocument(
  <Provider store={store}>
    <SmartParent />
  </Provider>
);
```

Thanks!

ps. That was easy... good sign I need to have some rest :)

Followup observation: the wrapper components generated by `connect()` do support taking `store` as a prop, which seems like it would be an alternate approach to passing it in to a smart component.  Also, it looks like the Enzyme library supports defining the context for a component being tested.

title: dispatch(action) calls reducer twice but this.props.function not
author: datoml

comments.body: If you're using `bindActionCreators` and `mapDispatchToProps`, the action creators _are already bound_. There is no need to call `dispatch()` on their return values. The whole point of `bindActionCreators()` is _not_ to call `dispatch()`. You should either `bindActionCreators()` and call them as is, or not use it, and call `dispatch()`.
Thank you for the explanation @gaearon.

title: Why does this work?
body:
So, after literally hours of moving things around, trudging through docs, etc., I finally got this to work:

``` js
const middleware = compose(
  applyMiddleware(promise, thunk),
  devTools(),
  persistState(window.location.href.match(/[?&]debug_session=([^&]+)\b/)),
);

// You may call this a finalCreateStore
const store = middleware(createStore)(reducer); // reducer is already combined up the chain
...
```

So...
- What gets `compose`d vs. `applyMiddleware`d?
- Why can't I `compose(promise, thunk, devTools(), persist(...))`?
- Why can't I `applyMiddleware(promise, thunk, devTools())`
- Why can't I do `compose(..., createStore, reducer)`?

Sorry if these are "newbie" questions, but my take was that things are either `actions`, `actionCreators`, `reducers`, or `middleware`, so I thought all of the above was middleware?
author: ericclemmons

comments.body:
DevTools is not middleware.
persistState is not middleware. 

Both are "store enhancers".
Incidentally applyMiddleware is also one.
That's why they're on the same level.

It's the opposite:
- The basic concept is "store enhancer". It's createStore => createStore.
- Store enhancers are too powerful, usually all you want is dispatch => dispatch (and have a reference to store for good measure).
- There's a store enhancer called applyMiddleware().

Ok, so if I understand correctly...
- middleware _can directly handle events from action creators_, which is why they get wrapped by the `applyMiddleware` "store enhancer".
- Store enhancers aren't really part of the action dispatching process/changing/handing responsibility, but are there for adding features _using_ the store?

Store enhancers can do pretty much anything. For example they can wrap reducers, override any store method, or map state.

The only thing middleware does is wrap dispatch() method. It's less powerful but easier to write correctly.

Everything that middleware can do, store enhancers can do. But they're more complicated to implement so we don't talk about them much in the docs.

If all you need is wrap dispatch, write middleware. If you need more exotic things write a store enhancer.

Also check out applyMiddleware() source.

Yeah you could do that.

One side effect is that you might want to apply middleware twice.

What I meant to say is that there are cases where you want to apply some middleware, then some enhancer, and then some more middleware. For example if you want to put logger after some enhancer that generates actions you want to log.

Not saying it's a common use case but it's something that gets lost with the signature above. That's the reason we don't include such createStoreWith in the core, too.
Ah, good explanation.  This reminds me much more of doing Koa-middleware where you `yield next` and create very special little sandwiches :)

Another question (last one!):  if "middleware" were all just store enhancers (but only concerned themselves with the dispatch part), would it then read:

``` js
compose(
  thunkEnhancer,
  promiseEnhancer,
  devTools(),
  ...
)(createStore)(reducer, initialState);
```

If that's correct, then `applyMiddleware` is really _enhancing_ `thunk` and `promise` to be a "store enhancer" like the rest of the chain...
If we want to be precise about it, `applyMiddleware()` is a function whose arguments are middleware and which returns a store enhancer.
@acdlite I think that's clarification I (we) needed. Finally arrived to that conclusion, but   that distinction hasn't been clear.  Thanks guys!

title: Displaying time?
body:
I have a lot of components that update every seconds based on `Date.now()`. However, performing these updates through the redux stores makes dev-tools and logging extremely slow, spammed and unusable.

Does anyone have any suggestions on how one can handle this in the best way?

One way I was thinking about was that the components themselves have a time subscription that calls `setState` with the current time, i.e. time updates are local to the component. The time has (mostly) no logical meaning only visual.
author: ronag

comments.body:
How are you using time in your reducers? Since time is an external state, and introduces non-pure effects into store, it should probably be kept external. If you're using React, I would handle it internal to your components. 

Say, for example, you have a list of comments on a blog and you want to have the timestamp next to each comment update in real time ("1 minute ago" changes to "2 minutes ago", etc.). I wouldn't track that in my redux store, as that's a display concern. I would either have each comment component set up a `setInterval` and re-render as needed. Or I would set that up at the top level comment list container and pass down the current time as a prop to each comment component and have them re-render as needed.
Sounds reasonable. Thank you for the feedback.

title: Showing notifications from reducers
author: bkniffler

comments.body:
Your reducers (using 1.0 terminology) should not contain any side effects. They should be pure functions, just like `render()` function in React.

You want to do side effects in action creators instead. Can you show your action creator for `CRUD_SAVE_SUCCESS`?
This makes sense!
